body.p: What is not an inorganic component of bone?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Calcium is an elemental mineral and does not contain organic carbon.
Correct. Collagen is a protein, which is organic.
Incorrect. Phosphorus is an elemental mineral and does not contain organic carbon.
Incorrect. Hydroxyapatite contains calcium and phosphorus, but no organic content.

body.p: How are the organic and inorganic components of bone integrated?

input.choice: Hydroxyapatite nanocrystals integrate with collagen fibers.
Cortical bone is all inorganic and spongy bone is all organic.
There are no organic components of bone, it is all calcium.

feedback.p: Correct. At the nanoscale, the hydroxyapatite (with calcium and phosphate) binds with collagen fibers to form lamellae.
Incorrect. These components do not integrate at the molecule level.
Incorrect. All macroscopic bone structures contain organic and inorganic parts.
Incorrect. Bone contains organic collagen as well as cells.

body.p: How is water integrated into cartilage?

input.choice: There is one water molecule per collagen protein.
A network of negatively charged glycosylated proteins attract water.
Blood vessels in cartilage drive the water in.
There is a pocket for water that is two to five centimeters in diameter.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Water is attracted by the glycosylations, and many water molecules are involved.
Correct. Water is drawn into glycosylations.
Incorrect. There are no blood vessels in cartilage.
Incorrect. Water is incorporated at the molecular and macromolecular level, not at the macroscopic level.

body.p: Which is not part of mature bone?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The extracellular matrix of bone contains collagen.
Correct. Proteoglycans are part of mature cartilage or immature bone.
Incorrect. Bone contains osteocytes and is constantly being remodeled with osteoclasts and osteoblasts.
Incorrect. Blood vessels flow through bone to nourish the bone cells.

body.p: In osteogenesis imperfecta, which molecule is altered?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Calcium levels may be altered, but the mutation is present in the collagen.
Incorrect. Mutations may occur in proteoglycans, but they do not cause osteogenesis imperfecta.
Correct. A mutation in the protein prevents proper formation of the extracellular matrix.
Incorrect. Hydroxyapatite levels may be altered, but the mutation is present in the collagen.

body.p: Which nanostructure is responsible for compression resistance in bone?

feedback.p: Incorrect. This is close, but in the bone, calcium is present in the crystalline hydroxyapatite.
Incorrect. Proteoglycans resist compressive forces, but mostly in cartilage. In bone, hydroxyapatite resists compression.
Incorrect. Collagen resists tension, not compression.
Correct. The crystal hydroxyapatite resists compression.

body.p: Which nanostructure is responsible for compression resistance in cartilage?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Mineralized calcium is present in bone.
Correct. Proteoglycans and the associated water resist compression in cartilage.
Incorrect. Collagen resists tensile force.
Incorrect. Hydroxyapatite resists compressive forces, but in bone. In cartilage, proteoglycans resist compression.

body.p: Which nanostructure is responsible for tensile resistance in bone?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Calcium is part of hydroxyapatite, which resists compression in bone.
Incorrect. Proteoglycans are primarily used to resist compression in cartilage.
Correct. Collagen, since it has a coiled-coil triple helix, is resistant to tension.
Incorrect. Hydroxyapatite resists compression in bone.

body.p: Which cells secrete osteoid?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Osteoclasts cleave bone (remember the "c" in "clasts" matches the "c" in "cleave").
Incorrect. Osteocytes are sensor cells in bone.
Correct. Osteoblasts build bone (remember the "b" in "blasts" matches the "b" in "build").
Incorrect. Macrophages are immune cells.

body.p: Which cells transform within the bone?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Osteoclasts and osteocytes are different types of cells. Osteoblasts become osteocytes.
Correct. After building the bone, osteoblasts embed themselves in the bone and become osteocytes.
Incorrect. It's the other way around: osteoblasts become osteocytes.
Incorrect. Osteoclasts and osteocytes are different types of cells. Osteoblasts become osteocytes.

body.p: Which cells are osteoporosis drugs intended to inhibit?

feedback.p: Correct. Osteoporosis drugs reduce bone loss by inhibiting osteoclasts.
Incorrect. Osteoporosis drugs inhibit osteoclasts.
Incorrect. You may think that osteoporosis drugs promote osteoblast function, but it’s easier to inhibit osteoclast function.
Incorrect. However, osteoclasts (which are inhibited by osteoporosis drugs) and macrophages are similar cells.

body.p: Which is not part of mature cartilage?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Mature cartilage contains collagen.
Incorrect. Mature cartilage contains proteoglycans.
Incorrect. Cartilage contains chondrocytes.
Correct. Cartilage does not contain blood vessels, which makes repair challenging and makes it take a long time.

content.p: For the following, identify the macroscopic structures of compact bone.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Lamellae are microscopic mineralized fibrils.
Correct. Lamellae in compact bone form tubular structures called osteons.
Incorrect. Lamellae in spongy bone form trabeculae.

no_response.feedback: You did not answer the question.

body.p: Where are osteocytes found within the osteons?

input.choice: there are no cells in the osteons

feedback.p: Correct. Lacunae are oriented around the central canal, parallel with the osteons.
Incorrect. Lamellae are mineralized fibrils.
Incorrect. The central canal contains vessels.
Incorrect. Cells are required to remodel compact bone, and resident osteocytes sense changes.

body.p: What is in the central canal formed by osteons in compact bone?

feedback.p: Correct. Blood vessels travel through the central canal of compact bone to provide nutrients and remove wastes to the osteocytes in the lacunae.
Incorrect. Blood vessels are in the central canal.
Incorrect. Blood vessels are in the central canal of compact bone; bone marrow is in contained within spongy bone.
Incorrect. Blood vessels are in the central canal.

body.p: Which bones are formed via intramembranous ossification?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Intramembranous ossification is a specialized type of bone formation.
Incorrect. Intramembranous ossification is a specialized type of bone formation.
Correct. Intramembranous ossification is a specialized type of bone formation used only for flat bones, such as the skull.
Incorrect. Intramembranous ossification is a specialized type of bone formation.

body.p: For which type of fracture would serious reconstructive measures be needed?

feedback.p: Incorrect. A simple fracture can be set with a cast.
Incorrect. A greenstick fracture—a fracture that occurs in children when one side of a bone breaks, and the other side bends—can be set with a cast.
Correct. In a comminuted fracture, the bone shatters or breaks into several pieces, and must either be reconstructed or replaced.
Incorrect. A stress fracture is small, and may not require any treatment.

body.p: Why are older individuals encouraged to lift weights to help their bones and reduce the effects of osteoporosis?

input.choice: bones respond to and get stronger with force

feedback.p: Incorrect. That’s true, but bones themselves are force-responsive.
Correct. Bones are force-responsive.
Incorrect. Exercise is good for endocrine health, but weight-bearing exercises are good for bone strength.
Incorrect. Exercise is good for appetite, but weight-bearing exercises are good for bone strength.

body.p: How can reduced force on the cartilage in articulations, such as that experienced by astronauts in microgravity, lead to cell loss in cartilage?

input.choice: There is reduced fluid motion to the cells embedded in the cartilage.
Cells crawl out of the cartilage if they aren't needed.
There are no cells in cartilage.

feedback.p: Correct. Since cartilage does not have blood vessels, compression is required to move fluid in and out of cartilage; fluid movement is required to move in nutrients, take away waste and provide mechanical stimulation.
Incorrect. Cells die from lack of nutrients and mechanical stimulation.
Incorrect. Cells die from lack of nutrients and mechanical stimulation.
Incorrect. There are no blood vessels, but there are cells in cartilage.

body.p: Hydroxyapatite is:

input.choice: an organic mixture of type I and type II collagen
an inorganic mixture containing calcium and phosphate
responsible for the ability of long bones to flex

feedback.p: Incorrect.
Incorrect.
Correct.
Incorrect.

body.p: A main role of proteoglycans in bone is to:

input.choice: attract water that acts to cushion compression

feedback.p: Correct.
Incorrect.
Incorrect.
Incorrect.

body.p: The main role of osteocytes is to:

feedback.p: Correct.
Incorrect.
Incorrect.
Incorrect.

body.p: Which classification of bone has a collection of specialized cells, organic extracellular matrix proteins, and and inorganic salt crystals?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Compact bone has all three of these characteristics but so does spongy bone.
Incorrect. Spongy bone has all three of these characteristics but so does compact bone.
Correct. Both classifications of bone have these characteristics.
Incorrect. Both classifications of bone have these characteristics.

body.p: Which of the following is correctly paired with its description?

input.choice: Flat bones are formed by endochondral ossification.
Long bones are formed by intramembranous ossification.
Endochondral ossification is the formation of bone between layers of connective tissue.
Intramembranous ossification is the formation of bone between layers of connective tissue.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Flat bones are formed by intramembranous ossification.
Incorrect. Long bones are formed by endochondral ossification.
Incorrect. Endochondral ossification is the formation of bone from a hyaline cartilage blueprint.
Correct. Intramembranous ossification is the formation of bone between layers of connective tissue.

body.p: Which of the following is correctly matched with its components?

input.choice: Nanoscale -- compact and spongy bone combine to form whole bone
Submicron scale -- mineral crystals are embedded within collagen
Micron scale -- lamellae form osteons or trabeculae
Macroscale -- mineralized fibrils are organized into lamellae

feedback.p: Incorrect. Nanoscale includes the mineral crystals embedded within the collagen.
Incorrect. Submicron scale is when the mineralized fibrils are organized into lamella.
Correct. Lamellae are formed into osteons or trabeculae at the micron level.
Incorrect. Macroscale is the combination of compact and spongy bone combined to form the whole bone.

body.p: What feature of the hydroxyapatite crystals allow them to easily exchange ions?

input.choice: They are micron sized with a small surface area
They are nano sized with a large surface area

feedback.p: Incorrect. They do add to the compressive strength of bone but this does not impact their ability to exchange ions.
Incorrect. Hydroxyapatite crystals are nano sized not micron sized.
Correct. Hydroxyapatite crystals are nano sized with a large surface area, which makes it easy to exchange ions.
Incorrect. The fluoride crystals add more strength to the bone but do not increase the surface area of the crystals.

body.p: Which of the following is not a function of phosphorous?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Phosphorous is utilized to make ATP and cellular energy.
Incorrect. Phosphorous is needed for cell growth.
Incorrect. Phosphorous is part of RNA and DNA backbones.
Correct. Calcium is the element that plays a key role in blood clotting.

body.p: If a person was lacking Type I collagen which of the following would occur?

input.choice: There would be no effect on bone because Type I collagen is found in cartilage only

feedback.p: Incorrect. The bones would have less flexibility because collagen adds flexibility.
Correct. In bone formation a cartilage matrix must be deposited first.
Incorrect. Bones would be more brittle.
Incorrect. Type I collagen is the primary form of collagen in bone.

body.p: Which of the following is properly matched with its function?

input.choice: Osteoclasts -- break down and reabsorb bone
Osteoblasts -- deposit and build new bone
Osteocytes -- mature bone cells that act as sensors for repair
All of the above are correctly matched with their function.

feedback.p: Partially correct. This is properly matched to its function, but so are all of the others.
Partially correct. This is properly matched to its function, but so are all of the others.
Partially correct. This is properly matched to its function, but so are all of the others.
Correct. These are all properly matched with their functions.

body.p: Which of the following fractures is not properly matched with its description?

input.choice: Greenstick fracture -- occurs in children when one side of a bone breaks, and the other side bends
Impacted fracture -- one end of the fractured bone is forced into the interior of the other end
Simple fracture -- ends of the broken bone break through the skin
Stress fractures -- incomplete fractures of the bone caused by over use

feedback.p: Incorrect. Greenstick fractures do occur in children when one side of a bone breaks, and the other side bends.
Incorrect. An impacted fracture does have one end of the bone forced into the interior of the other end.
Correct. Simple fractures do not have bone ends that break through the skin.
Incorrect. Stress fractures are incomplete fractures of the bone caused by overuse.

body.p: Why do we splint a bone after a fracture?

input.choice: To prevent infection from an open wound

feedback.p: Incorrect. Splinting will decrease muscle strength.
Incorrect. Splinting does not close an open wound.
Incorrect. Immobilizing the bone will decrease pain.
Correct. A bone will heal more quickly if it is immobile.
